Critiques against the possibility of a late surge, or university-driven reversal, correctly point out that this year features both unique, hard bottlenecks (the May-June freeze, expanded vetting, capacity caps) and a real demand redirection on the Chinese side that make any heroic late catch-up implausible. Through my own perspective in China Studies, the social and peer-driven retreat from US applications only adds to this. Group input reinforced the weight of structural, not merely psychological, obstacles. To the extent that some argued for an even higher probability (notably SociologySocialNetworkTheory and PoliticalScienceInternationalRelationsTheory), their reasoning aligns with my sense of downside risk, especially as no evidence of catch-up exists in the late summer window. Therefore, I slightly revise my probability upward to 90%.

question_details.title: Will the number of new F-1 visas issued by the US to students from China or India decrease by >10% in FY 2025? (China)
question_details.description:
This question is synced with an identical question on Metaculus. The original question opened on 2025-08-13 21:00:00 and can be found [here](https://www.metaculus.com/questions/39113). This question will resolve to the same value as the synced question. The original question's background info at this time is below. 

In 2024, the United States [hosted](https://x.com/CIS_org/status/1933204000129577288) a record 1,582,808 foreign students:

* 422,335 were from India.
* 329,541 were from China. 

A substantial majority of international students in the US, especially those attending accredited colleges and universities, are authorized to enter and study in the US using the [F-1 visa](https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/us-visas/study/student-visa.html). 

In past years, the number of students from India newly issued the visas have been as follows:

| Fiscal year | F‑1 visas issued to Indian nationals |
| ----------- | ------------------------------------ |
| **FY 2024** | **86,067**                           |
| **FY 2023** | **130,730**                          |
| **FY 2022** | **115,115**                          |
| **FY 2021** | **80,451**                           |
| **FY 2020** | **15,323**                           |
| **FY 2019** | **43,714**                           |

The numbers for students from mainland China have been as follows:

| Fiscal year | F‑1 visas issued to Chinese nationals |
| ----------- | ------------------------------------- |
| **FY 2024** | **82,654**                            |
| **FY 2023** | **85,950**                            |
| **FY 2022** | **61,894**                            |
| **FY 2021** | **90,310**                            |
| **FY 2020** | **14,436**                            |
| **FY 2019** | **105,775**                           |

According to the [Samotsvety Forecasting Group](https://samotsvety.com/p/international-students-in-the-us?utm_campaign=post\&utm_medium=web), an elite group of professional forecasters:

> Recently, the United States has been changing its approach to immigration, generally favoring more protectionist and nativist rhetoric and policy. We have seen:

> \- High-profile visa revocations and deportations

> \- New policies creating extra hurdles for international students, such as social media vetting and temporary suspensions of visa issuance

> \- Increased funding and enforcement activities by immigration authorities (ICE)

> \- Arbitrary SEVP (student permit) revocations

Samotsvety has assessed a 76% chance of a >10% decline in F-1 visas for Chinese students and a 66% chance for Indian students, with the following reasoning:

> As of May 2025, the number of new visas for FY2025 was [substantially lower than FY2024](https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/legal/visa-law0/visa-statistics/nonimmigrant-visa-statistics.html) for both China and India. This decrease continued a trend from 2024, when new F-1 visa numbers dropped by [34% for India and 3.6% for China](https://travel.state.gov/content/dam/visas/Statistics/AnnualReports/). In principle, this decline could be counterbalanced by a rebound during the summer, when the majority of new student visas are issued. But the lower visa numbers over the past year suggest that studying in the US has become less appealing. Actions by the Trump administration this year may accelerate this trend, making potential international students more cautious about studying in the US. Chinese students in particular may be wary in light of comments by the State Department about mass visa revocation for Chinese students.

> On top of decreased demand, the [visa interview freeze](https://www.americanimmigrationcouncil.org/important-update-regarding-f-m-and-j-visa-interview-appointments/#:~:text=UPDATE%20\(6/19/25,The%20pause%20is%20temporary.) from May 27-June 18 blocked new visas for a large fraction of the peak season, limiting the time window for a potential rebound. We expect this to lead to a decrease in processed applications, and a lower number of new F-1’s overall. [New rules for social media vetting](https://www.state.gov/releases/office-of-the-spokesperson/2025/06/announcement-of-expanded-screening-and-vetting-for-visa-applicants) may decrease the acceptance rate, though we believe this will have a smaller effect than the reduction in the overall number of applications.

> A few sources of uncertainty limit the confidence of our forecast. The number of F-1 visas is volatile from year to year, particularly for individual countries. If last year’s change reflects a temporary drop rather than a sustained trend, baseline volatility and regression to the mean could lead to higher F-1 issuance in 2025, counterbalancing the effects of the visa freeze and new social media vetting. Universities facing funding challenges may also be incentivized to accept more international students, who often pay more in tuition than US students.

question_details.resolution_criteria:
This question is a subquestion of a group question. This subquestion specifically targets the option 'China'. The resolution criteria for the parent question is below. 

This question resolves as **Yes** for the subquestions, according to the US State Department's [Nonimmigrant Visa Statistics](https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/legal/visa-law0/visa-statistics/nonimmigrant-visa-statistics.html) portal, as follows:

* If the number of F-1 visas issued to Indian nationals is less than 77,460 for FY 2025.
* If the number of F-1 visas issued to Chinese nationals (typically listed as "China - mainland" in data tables) is less than 74,389 for FY 2025.
question_details.fine_print:
Scroll down to the "Nonimmigrant Visa Issuances by Visa Class and by Nationality" section at the resolution source. The expected file name, anticipated to be posted in January 2026 based on previous experience, will be *FY2025 NIV Detail Table (PDF)*. For example, the 2024 numbers can be accessed at [this PDF](https://travel.state.gov/content/dam/visas/Statistics/Non-Immigrant-Statistics/NIVDetailTables/FY24NIVDetailTable.pdf), with the F-1 visa numbers for China and India both on page 9 of 42, listed as 82,654 and 86,067, respectively.

Question resolves according to the first numbers reported that are accessed by Metaculus; later revisions will not cause the question to be re-resolved.

news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Trump's Built an Invisible Border Wall. It's Costing All of Us.**
The article argues that President Trump’s administration’s visa‑policy changes have created an "invisible border wall" that is harming the U.S. economy and society.  It cites that in fiscal year 2024 U.S. Customs and Border Protection encountered over 2 million people at the southern border, while the State Department issued almost 11 million temporary visas and hundreds of thousands of green cards during the same period, showing a mismatch between border enforcement and visa issuance.  The piece notes that the State Department has sharply limited waivers of visa interviews, which will "supercharge already crushing wait times," and that U.S. consulates are experiencing bottlenecks: a tourist visa at the Ciudad Juárez consulate now takes 11 months, the next appointment in Abu Dhabi is 18 months away, and wait times in India can exceed a year.  It reports that the department is reviewing more than 55 million visa holders for violations, and has revoked more than twice as many visas since the end of January as in the same period the previous year.  The article claims that expanded social‑media vetting of international student applicants will lead to a projected 30‑40 % plunge in new student arrivals this fall, costing universities $7 billion in revenue and wiping out 60 000 jobs.  Congress added a $250 "visa integrity" fee on top of the $185 application cost, and the U.S. Travel Association projects that the fee could cost the economy $11 billion over three years, including $9.4 billion in lost visitor spending and $1.3 billion in lost tax revenue.  A pilot program imposing visa bonds up to $15 000 for visitors from high‑overstay countries is also mentioned.  The article cites a travel ban that now restricts nationals from 19 countries, noting that in 2022 nearly 300 000 people from those countries arrived in the U.S. and that their households earned $3.2 billion in income, paid $715.6 million in taxes, and had $2.5 billion in spending power.  It warns that a potential expansion to 36 more countries could choke off further economic activity.  Recent data show that U.S. consulates issued 16 % fewer temporary visas and 20 % fewer green cards in May 2025 than in May 2024, and that over 300 000 fewer overseas visitors came to the U.S. during the first seven months of 2025 compared with the same period in 2024.  The World Travel and Tourism Council projects a 22 % plunge in international visitor spending this year, a $12.5 billion loss, and notes that the U.S. is the only country among 184 studied expected to see a decline.  The piece concludes that treating every visitor as a threat keeps out not only terrorists but also talent, paying students, families, and ordinary travelers whose spending supports American jobs, and warns that continued suspicion and obstruction could turn the U.S. into a country that fewer people want to visit or build a future in.
Original language: en
Publish date: September 08, 2025 04:24 PM
Source:[Slate Magazine](https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2025/09/immigration-trump-border-wall-visa-denials.html)

**Trump admin to limit visa durations for students, journalists**
The Trump administration has proposed new regulations that would impose fixed time limits on visas for foreign students, cultural exchange visitors and media members, replacing the current flexible 'duration of status' system that has been in place since 1978. The changes would cap F visas for international students and J visas for exchange visitors at four years maximum, while I visas for foreign media would be limited to 240 days with extension options. Currently, these visa holders can remain in the U.S. for the duration of their program or employment without fixed time limits. A Department of Homeland Security spokesperson said, 'For too long, past Administrations have allowed foreign students and other visa holders to remain in the U.S. virtually indefinitely, posing safety risks, costing untold amounts of taxpayer dollars and disadvantaging U.S. citizens.' The public has 30 days to comment on the measure, which mirrors a 2020 proposal that was later withdrawn by the Biden administration. The changes could significantly affect the 1.6 million international students on F visas. Overall, Chinese nationals represent roughly 25 % of all foreign students. A July 2025 report from the Institute of International Education (IIE) shows that international student enrollment has already dropped, with 35 % of surveyed schools reporting decreased applications this fall compared to 17 % the previous year. Fanta Aw, executive director and CEO of NAFSA: Association of International Educators, said, 'It will certainly act as an additional deterrent to international students choosing to study in the United States, to the detriment of American economies, innovation and global competitiveness.' The visa restrictions disproportionately impact Asian populations, who comprise approximately 13 million immigrants and represent the largest share of temporary visa holders nationwide. Enforcement has already intensified, with the State Department revoking over 6,000 student visas this year—nearly four times more than the same period in 2024—primarily for alleged overstays and legal violations. Simultaneously, the administration is reviewing over 55 million valid visa holders through 'continuous vetting' that includes social media monitoring and requires applicants to disable privacy settings during visa interviews. New screening protocols also target 'anti-American ideologies or activities,' though the State Department has not clearly defined these terms.
Original language: en
Publish date: September 08, 2025 03:48 PM
Source:[Yahoo](https://ca.news.yahoo.com/trump-admin-limit-visa-durations-154850251.html)

**Chinese and Indian Students Seek Refuge in Australia, Escalating Deportation Crisis**
The Epoch Times reports that nearly 100,000 foreign students in Australia are extending their stay by applying for asylum visas, with 98,979 applications rejected as of July 31 2025 and 27,100 still pending. 5,000 of those who lost their appeals are reportedly living illegally in the country.  The article cites former immigration deputy Abul Rizvi, who said, '里茲維呼籲政府採取緊急措施來處理等待遣返的人數不斷增加的問題', urging the government to increase deportations and crack down on intermediaries aiding fake refugees.  Between July 1 2024 and June 30 2025, Australia received 23,576 asylum applications, approved 4,036 (≈ 17 %) and rejected 24,924 (≈ 84 %).  Only 162 applicants were deported during that period.  Indian applicants submitted 2,596 applications, 5,633 were rejected (≈ 57 % of all rejections) and only 42–60 were approved (≈ 1–1.5 % of approvals).  Chinese applicants filed 2,494 applications, 3,538 were rejected (≈ 14 % of all rejections) and about 290 were approved (≈ 7 % of approvals).  The article also notes that in the 2006–2007 fiscal year, 103,000 international students arrived in Australia, 44 % finished their studies and returned home, 39 % obtained permanent residency, and 17 % stayed on temporary visas.  The Albanese government announced an increase of 25,000 places for international students in 2026, raising the total to 295,000.
Original language: zh
Publish date: September 08, 2025 03:55 AM
Source:[The Epoch Times](https://www.epochtimes.com/b5/25/9/8/n14589707.htm)

**Open US university doors to more of China's students  --  IF they love...**
The article argues that the United States should open its higher‑education system to more Chinese students, citing President Donald Trump’s proposal to admit 600,000 Chinese students and the White House’s clarification that the figure represented ‘two years’ worth of visas. It notes that, in reality, about 277,000 Chinese students are currently in the U.S., compared with 331,000 from India, and that fewer than 90,000 of those are undergraduates. The piece counters the myth that foreign students take seats from Americans by pointing out that, out of nearly 16 million U.S. undergraduates in fall 2023, 342,000 (≈2 %) were foreigners, and that 844,000 international students enrolled in graduate programs and paid full tuition, which subsidises scholarships and keeps many public‑university programs viable. A 2017 study is cited to show that foreign‑student tuition helped some states trim education budgets and avoid raising tuition for Americans. The author also highlights the economic and geopolitical benefits of retaining international students, claiming that the average graduate who stays in the U.S. reduces the national debt by millions over 30 years and that brain drain is a strategic advantage against authoritarian regimes. The article calls for enhanced social‑media vetting, direct questioning of applicants from authoritarian countries, exemption of foreigners with advanced STEM degrees from green‑card caps, and streamlined work visas for graduates. It concludes with a personal anecdote: ‘I came to the United States from Venezuela as an international student, driven by the desire for freedom and my opposition to socialism.’
Original language: en
Publish date: September 07, 2025 02:18 PM
Source:[New York Post](https://nypost.com/2025/09/07/opinion/open-us-universities-to-chinas-students-if-they-love-america/)

**Are Chinese Students Still Welcome in the U.S.?**
Trump recently announced that he would allow 600,000 Chinese students to study in the U.S. over the next two years, but U.S. immigration policy has tightened. The article reports that in the 2023/24 academic year, 112 million+ international students were enrolled in the U.S., a 6.6 % increase, with 277,398 Chinese students—a 4.2 % drop from the previous year. It cites a case of a Chinese student, Gu, who was denied entry at U.S. customs and barred from returning for five years. The piece quotes a Beijing Normal University senior, Zhang, who says '我觉得周围的同学大多数还是想去美国，别的不说，美国的就业市场是最好的，我们都听说有些学长研究生毕业后可以拿到十几万，甚至二十几万美金的年薪'. Dr. Cui Kai comments that after the Gu incident, parents’ inquiries about '入境口岸风控', '电子设备与学术资料携带规范' and '如何回答研究相关问题' rose sharply. The article notes that while Trump wants to increase Chinese student numbers, 2025 visa data shows a decline, and new DHS proposals restrict course changes for F‑1 students. Many Chinese students are applying to U.S. schools while also preparing to apply to Canada, the UK, and Australia.
Original language: zh
Publish date: September 07, 2025 06:54 AM
Source:[Deutsche Welle](https://www.dw.com/zh/%E7%BE%8E%E5%9B%BD%E4%BB%8D%E7%84%B6%E6%AC%A2%E8%BF%8E%E4%B8%AD%E5%9B%BD%E7%95%99%E5%AD%A6%E7%94%9F%E5%90%97/a-73893550)

**US tightens rules for Green Cards and H-1B visas**
The Trump administration has intensified restrictions on legal immigration, targeting H‑1B visas, green‑card holders, and international students. A proposed wage‑based selection system for H‑1B visas would give priority to applicants whose employers offer higher salaries. The administration is also pursuing revocation of citizenship and denaturalization of green‑card holders who commit crimes or under‑report income. New "neighbourhood investigation" procedures require testimonial letters from neighbours, employers, and co‑workers before naturalisation. **Beyond CAA: India widens protection for migrants fleeing persecution, 2024 new relief cutoff**
India’s Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) has issued the Immigration and Foreigners (Exemption) Order, 2025, extending protection to religious minorities who entered India on or before 31 December 2024 without valid passports or with expired documents. The order, which supersedes the earlier Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) that covered arrivals only before 31 December 2014, guarantees that Hindus, Sikhs, Buddhists, Jains, Parsis and Christians will not be deported. However, the exemption excludes foreigners convicted of serious crimes such as terrorism, espionage, rape, murder, human trafficking, drug trafficking, child abuse, cybercrime, racketeering, counterfeit documents or cryptocurrency offences. The order also empowers state and Union Territory authorities to detain illegal immigrants until deportation and requires carriers transporting undocumented individuals to return them to their country of origin, except in cases involving forged documents that cannot be detected without expert analysis, stowaways or aircraft diverted for reasons beyond carrier control. To strengthen oversight, biometric data collection is mandated for all foreigners applying for visas or registering as Overseas Citizens of India, and border forces such as the Border Security Force (BSF) and the Indian Coast Guard are tasked with capturing biometric and demographic details of illegal entrants before sending them back. Employment of foreign nationals in critical sectors such as power, water and petroleum is now restricted, and special permission is required for foreigners undertaking mountaineering expeditions. Exemptions remain for Indian defence personnel and their families, citizens of Nepal and Bhutan under specific conditions, Tibetan refugees with registration certificates, and registered Sri Lankan Tamil nationals who took shelter in India before 9 January 2015. The order balances humanitarian protection for persecuted minorities with national security safeguards, providing breathing space for vulnerable groups while leaving the question of citizenship unresolved.

**Asylum claims from study visa holders drop from record high**
According to new Home Office data released on 21 August, asylum claims by people who entered the UK on a study visa fell sharply after reaching record levels. In 2024 there were 16,200 such claims, more than triple the 2018 figure when records began. In the first two quarters of 2025, the number dropped to 6,700 from 8,100 in the same period last year, a 10 % decline in the latest year. The Home Office noted, 'While study visas have remained the most common visa to claim asylum on, claims have decreased in the latest year by 10 per cent.' The decline is partly due to a fall in the total number of study visas issued – 431,725 were granted in the year to June 2025, an 18 % drop from the previous year. Of these, 96 % (413,921) were for main applicants and 17,804 for dependants, an 81 % year‑on‑year drop in dependant visas versus a modest 4 % decline in main applicants. Despite the overall fall, asylum claimants who previously held a study visa or were dependants still represented 3 % of all study visas in the most recent 12 months. Nationality trends show Chinese students remained the largest group with 99,919 visas (24 % of total, 7 % decline), while Indian students accounted for 98,014 visas (24 %, 11 % decline) but rose in the second half of the year, potentially overtaking Chinese students. Pakistani nationals made up 9 % of visas, the US 7 % increase, and Nigerian students saw a 25 % overall decline. Master’s‑level study remains the main driver of international mobility, with over 60 % of recent sponsored study visas issued for master’s programmes; 81 % of Indian students and 59 % of Chinese students entered at master’s level. The rise in former students claiming asylum has prompted policy responses, including the White Paper on immigration that proposes cutting the post‑study stay for international graduates from two years to 18 months, following stricter visa rules introduced in January last year that limited dependant visas to research‑based postgraduate programmes.

summary:
All experts forecast a high probability that the number of new F-1 visas issued to students from China in FY 2025 will decrease by more than 10% relative to FY 2024, thus predicting a 'Yes' resolution for the question. Their probability estimates range from 80% to 90%, with most clustering at 85% or above.

Key factors cited across disciplines include: 1) A significant administrative shock from a May–June 2025 visa interview freeze during peak issuance season, causing a direct reduction in processing capacity; 2) New policies under the Trump administration, such as stricter social media and ideological vetting, higher visa fees, a surge in F-1 visa revocations, and fixed duration proposals—all increasing barriers and deterring applicants; 3) A perceptible chilling effect on Chinese applicants amplified by news of denials and deportations, network effects, and negative sentiment propagated in both Chinese and international communities; 4) A redirection of Chinese students to alternative destinations like Australia, Canada, and the UK, though these countries themselves have also tightened policies but to a lesser degree than the US; 5) US university advocacy and efforts to recover student flows are acknowledged but judged insufficient to offset federal bottlenecks and stronger deterrents; 6) Base rates show that >10% annual drops outside the pandemic are rare, but this year’s combined administrative, policy, and demand shocks are judged historically atypical and sufficiently large to override mean reversion or late recoveries.

While some experts note residual uncertainty due to volatility, the small possibility of a late-season surge in issuance, or exceptional university interventions, all agree that real-time data (notably a ~15% YoY drop in May 2025, rising revocation/denial rates, and evidence of ongoing bottlenecks) support a strong expectation of a decline exceeding 10%. Scenario descriptions align in projecting that only an unprecedented surge in late processing or demand resilience would keep 2025 numbers above the 10% decline threshold. All specialists, whether from administrative, legal, international relations, economic, or sociological perspectives, converge on the conclusion that mid-year trajectory, policy context, and sentiment make a Yes outcome (issuance below 74,389 F-1 visas to Chinese students) highly likely.
